title: Roman Kemp screams as he’s drenched for failing spelling test
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Roman Kemp’s #NoMoneyRoadTrip is not getting off to the best start, after he had a bucket of water dumped over his head.

The Capital FM presenter is attempting to travel 1,000 miles around the country for Global’s Make Some Noise charity – but without any money or his mobile phone.

Which sounds like a ridiculously hard Apprentice task…

Niall Horan hasn’t made things any easier for the 26-year-old, challenging him to take part in a spelling test at Lewis Capaldi’s old school, St Kentigern’s RC Academy, in Scotland.

Advertisement

Advertisement

In a bid to win a pair of much-needed thermal socks, Lewis asked him to spell the word ‘Sauchiehall,’ a well-known street in Glasgow.

Unfortunately for the presenter, the word is spelled absolutely nothing like how it sounds, so he failed miserably.

Roman Kemp is currently on the road for a charity stunt (Picture: WireImage)

He suggested ‘S-O-C-K-E-Y-H-A-L-L’, which was nowhere near, and meant he was punished by the school children.

Heading outside, they poured a bucket of water over his head and pelted him with flour.

Not ideal when you’ve got to make your way to Edinburgh for the next task, soaking wet and covered in powder…

Roman hasn’t had the best couple of days, after he was inked by Niall Horan for another charity stunt.

The former One Direction star blessed Martin Kemp’s son with a tattoo of his new single, Nice To Meet Ya.

However, it turns out the 26-year-old has ever really used a tattoo gun before, and managed to make a rather awkward mistake.

Instead of inking the title, he accidentally wrote, ‘Nice To Melt Ya,’ which is definitely not the same thing.

Roman was a good sport about the error, and still showed his new design off on Instagram.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But Niall was having none of it, commenting: ‘Think it gets worse every time I look at it and that’s hard to do.’

Maybe stick to the singing, hun…
